docs.lead_paragraph: The Gerber Products Company agreed today to a delay in its $150 million lawsuit against Maryland officials and promised to cooperate with a state administrative inquiry into how bits of glass got into jars of baby food. The action came as the Federal Food and Drug Administration reported it had received 85 confirmed and unconfirmed complaints of glass fragments in Gerber jars in 16 states. The agency said it had confirmed the presence of glass in 14 of 40 opened jars it had checked. But the F.D.A. said a recall of Gerber products was unwarranted.

headline.main: BABY-FOOD MAKER AND MARYLAND ACCEPT JOINT INQUIRY ON GLASS BITS

docs.snippet: The Gerber Products Company agreed today to a delay in its $150 million lawsuit against Maryland officials and promised to cooperate with a state administrative inquiry into how bits of glass got into jars of baby food.   The action came as the...

byline.original: By JAMES BARRON, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Gerber Products Company filed a $150 million lawsuit today charging Maryland officials with creating a ''climate of fear and confusion'' by banning the sale of Gerber strained peaches after consumer reports of glass contamination. The company contended that the state's action was arbitrary and excessive and accused the state of making false statements. Gov. Harry Hughes ordered the ban Friday, and it took effect Sunday night. ''Gerber strongly believes that the unilateral conduct of the Governor of the state of Maryland has only created a climate of fear and confusion among the consuming public at a time when copy-cat actions should not be encouraged by acts of public officials,'' Kenneth Peirce, a Gerber vice president, said in a statement.

headline.main: GERBER FOODS SUES MARYLAND IN GLASS CONTAMINATION BAN
